title: Hashing Algorithms

subtopics.title: SHA-1 Algorithm

subtopics.title: SHA-256 Algorithm

subtopics.title: SHA-3 Algorithm

mainQuiz.title: Hashing Algorithms Fundamentals
mainQuiz.description: Test your understanding of various hashing algorithms, their properties, and security implications.

questions.question: Which property of hash functions ensures that it's computationally infeasible to find two different inputs that produce the same hash?
questions.explanation: Collision resistance ensures that finding two different inputs that hash to the same output is computationally infeasible, which is crucial for security applications.

questions.question: Why is MD5 no longer recommended for security purposes?
questions.explanation: MD5 is cryptographically broken as researchers have demonstrated efficient methods to find collisions, making it unsuitable for security applications.

questions.question: What is the output size of SHA-256?
questions.explanation: SHA-256 produces a 256-bit (32-byte) hash value, providing a good balance between security and efficiency.

questions.question: Which hashing algorithm was selected by NIST as the winner of the SHA-3 competition?
questions.explanation: Keccak was selected as the winner of the SHA-3 competition in 2012 and standardized as SHA-3 due to its unique design and security properties.

questions.question: What is the recommended replacement for MD5 in file integrity checking?
questions.explanation: Any modern cryptographic hash function (SHA-3, SHA-256, or BLAKE2) is suitable for file integrity checking, as they all provide strong security properties.
